groundtruth_answer: The catalyst's performance of #240.9 mol$_{H2}$ mol$_{metal}$$^{-1}$min$^{-1}$# results from the #bimetallic alloy and silica confinement# and a #highly accessible surface area through porous layers#.

Claims.text: Our processing protocol involving Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$@NC@mSiO$_{2}$ delivers outstanding hydrogen production performance, achieving a turnover frequency (TOF) value of up to 240.9 mol$_{H2}$ mol$_{metal}$$^{-1}$min$^{-1}$ at 298 K. During the stability test, the mSiO$_{2}$ shell prevented the loss of the nanoalloy, demonstrating impressive durability with a negligible decline of less than 0.8% for 30 cycles. The high activity and exceptional stability demonstrated by our catalyst notably surpass those of other noble-metal-free catalysts reported to date. These results reported here may open new avenues for designing stable catalysts using earth-abundant raw materials for hydrogen evolution reactions.
Claims.Claim: Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$@NC@mSiO$_{2}$ catalyst achieves a turnover frequency (TOF) of 240.9 mol$_{H2}$ mol$_{metal}$$^{-1}$min$^{-1}$ at 298 K with a negligible decline of less than 0.8% for 30 cycles.
Claims.Topic: Hydrogen production performance of a catalyst

Claims.text:
## Conclusion

In summary, we introduced a straightforward and facile method for fabricating magnetically recyclable Co-Cu@NC@mSiO$_{2}$ catalysts by utilizing mSiO$_{2}$-encapsulated Co-Cu-ZIF as a precursor through a thermal pyrolysis process. The optimized Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$@NC@mSiO$_{2 }$ catalyst demonstrated outstanding performance with a TOF of 240.9 mol$_{H2}$·mol$_{metal}$$^{-1}$·min$^{-1}$, surpassing the majority of noble-metal-free catalysts. More importantly, it exhibited remarkable stability, with a negligible decrease of less than 0.8% over 30 cycles. This enhanced performance originated primarily from the synergistic effects of the bimetallic alloy and silica confinement.
Claims.Claim: The Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$@NC@mSiO$_{2}$ catalyst demonstrated outstanding performance with a TOF of 240.9 mol$_{H2}$·mol$_{metal}$$^{-1}$·min$^{-1}$ and remarkable stability, with a negligible decrease of less than 0.8% over 30 cycles.
Claims.Topic: Magnetically recyclable catalysts for hydrogen production

Claims.text: Figure S15b illustrates that the catalytic performance of Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$@NC@mSiO$_{2}$-N, with a TOF of 196.9 mol$_{H2}$·mol$_{metal}$$^{-1}$·min$^{-1}$, is lower than that of Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$@NC@mSiO$_{2 }$(240.9 mol$_{H2}$·mol$_{metal}$$^{-1}$·min$^{-1}$). Thus, the excellent performance of Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$@NC@mSiO$_{2}$ may be attributed to a highly accessible surface area through the porous confinement layers, facilitating the transfer and diffusion of reactants and products.
Claims.Claim: Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$@NC@mSiO$_{2}$-N exhibits a lower catalytic performance with a TOF of 196.9 mol$_{H2}$·mol$_{metal}$$^{-1}$·min$^{-1}$ compared to Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$@NC@mSiO$_{2}$, which has a TOF of 240.9 mol$_{H2}$·mol$_{metal}$$^{-1}$·min$^{-1}$.
Claims.Topic: Catalytic performance and surface area in hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) catalysts

raw_query: What procedure is used to stabilize certain active sites on a carbon matrix, and how does this impact ORR performance and rechargeable battery power metrics?
optimized_query: What method stabilizes active metal sites on a carbon structure and influences reactions and power capabilities in energy devices?
groundtruth_answer: A #SiO$_{2}$-mediated two-step pyrolysis# method stabilizes #Fe-N$_{4}$ sites#, improving #ORR performance# and achieving #217 mW cm$^{-2}$# peak power and longevity in #ZABs#.

Claims.text:
## ABSTRACT

Atomically dispersed Fe-N-C catalysts are a promising alternative to platinum group metal (PGM) catalysts for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). However, attaining efficient ORR activity and superior stability in Fe-N-C catalysts is still crucial yet challenging. Herein, we report a rational SiO$_{2}$-mediated two-step pyrolysis strategy for stabilizing densely exposed Fe-N$_{4 }$active sites on hierarchically porous carbon (HP-Fe-N-C/2). Benefiting from the high density of accessible Fe-N$_{4 }$sites and the high graphitization degree of carbon support, the obtained HPFe-N-C/2 catalyst demonstrates outstanding activity and stability for ORR in both alkaline and acidic media.
Claims.Claim: Atomically dispersed Fe-N-C catalysts demonstrate outstanding activity and stability for ORR in both alkaline and acidic media due to the high density of accessible Fe-N₄ sites and the high graphitization degree of carbon support.
Claims.Topic: Stabilization of Fe-N₄ active sites for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR)

Claims.text:
Up to now, PGM catalysts have been regarded as generally efficient catalysts to accelerate ORR [8,9]. However, the high price and scarcity of PGM catalysts greatly limit their large-scale commercialization [10 -13]. Therefore, for the widespread application of ZABs and PEMFCs, exploring high-performance and earth-abundant PGM-free catalysts has become a key research direction [14 -20].

To date, atomically dispersed Fe-N-C catalysts possess the highest ORR performance among the various PGM-free catalysts [18,21,22]. Atomic Fe-N$_{4 }$ sites have been confirmed as active sites for ORR by theoretical and experimental studies [23 -26]. Thus, increasing the density of Fe-N$_{4 }$sites is an effective strategy to boost ORR activity.
Claims.Claim: Atomically dispersed Fe-N-C catalysts possess the highest ORR performance among the various PGM-free catalysts, with atomic Fe-N₄ sites confirmed as active sites for ORR.
Claims.Topic: ORR performance of PGM-free catalysts

Claims.text: The subsequent adsorption and pyrolysis process further promote the creation of abundant Fe-N$_{4 }$active sites. Due to the synergistically advantageous features of densely exposed Fe-N$_{4 }$ sites, enhanced intrinsic activity of Fe-N$_{4 }$sites by pyridinic N and graphitic N dopants, and highly graphitized carbon matrix, the HP-Fe-N-C/2 exhibits outstanding ORR activity and stability in both alkaline and acidic media. The assembled ZAB displays a high peak power density of 217 mW cm GLYPH<0> 2 and long-life cycling stability for 1342 h. Moreover, the maximum output power in a PEMFC reaches 0.66 W cm GLYPH<0> $^{2}$.
Claims.Claim: The HP-Fe-N-C/2 catalyst exhibits outstanding ORR activity and stability due to the synergistically advantageous features of densely exposed Fe-N$_{4}$ sites, enhanced intrinsic activity of Fe-N$_{4}$ sites by pyridinic N and graphitic N dopants, and highly graphitized carbon matrix.
Claims.Topic: Catalyst performance in oxygen reduction reaction (ORR)

raw_query: What conditions lead to a consistent interface layer and resistance behavior without unwanted precipitates in specific Zn-based battery electrolytes?

Claims.text: In Figure 4 e, the formation of a Zn$_{4}$SO$_{4}$(OH)$_{6}$ · x H$_{2}$O (ZSH) layer on the surface of Zn was observed after 5 cycles in ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolytes, and the characteristic diffraction peaks of ZSH gradually intensified during subsequent cycles. Conversely, no significant signal corresponding to ZSH was detected in the Gln/ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte during a cycle from 5 to 50 ( Figure 4 f). The findings presented above further support the effectiveness of the Gln/ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte in suppressing side reactions and facilitating the formation of a stable SEI during electrochemical processes.

In conclusion, the aforementioned evidence and analysis demonstrate that the Gln/ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte exerts a significant inhibitory effect on byproduct formation at the Zn surface, thereby effectively preventing uncontrolled dendrite growth and facilitating uniform deposition of Zn. Consequently, this leads to the development of a stable SEI film.

As illustrated in Figure 4 c, the electrode surface in the ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte is covered with abundant clusters of loosely disordered flake-like and hexagonal byproducts of Zn dendrites, resulting in an extremely rough surface. This indicates the uncontrolled deposition of Zn and continuous side reactions between the Zn anode and ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolytes. In contrast, a flat and homogeneous surface morphology is achieved in the Gln/ ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte, suggesting that the addition of Gln facilitates the formation of stable SEI films ( Figure 4 d). Furthermore, the chemical phase transition at the anode interface was monitored by ex situ XRD analysis in different cyclic states.

raw_query: What factors lead to the improvement in cement's ability to bind chloride ions, considering particle dimension and composition?
optimized_query: How do variations in CDs size, related phase changes, and specific chemical groups collectively enhance the chloride binding capacity in modified cement?
groundtruth_answer: Chloride binding in cement improves due to smaller #CDs sizes#, increased #C$_{b}$ value#, and enhanced impact from #oxygen-containing groups# and #N-doped CDs#.

Claims.text: The consequences demonstrate that the chloride binding capacity in cement modified by CDs with average sizes of 1.73, 5.79, and 12.37 nm increases by 41%, 20%, and 14% respectively, compared with that of the blank group after 28-d immersion in 3 mol/L NaCl solution. This testifies that the chloride binding capacity of CDs-incorporated cement is negatively correlative with CDs sizes. The related mechanism is that CDs with smaller sizes can provide more nucleation sites to promote cement hydration, further advancing the production of C -S -H gels and monosulfate (Ms), thus more markedly enhancing the physical adsorption and chemical binding of chloride ions in cement pastes.
Claims.Claim: The chloride binding capacity of cement modified by carbon dots (CDs) increases with decreasing CDs size, enhancing chloride binding in cement pastes.
Claims.Topic: Chloride binding capacity in cement modified by CDs

Claims.text:
And the chloride binding capacity in diverse CDs-modified paste specimens is determined through the equilibrium tests. Crucially, the relevant mechanism is reasonably revealed based on the phase alteration. The main conclusions are shown as follows:

(2) The relationship between chloride binding ability of cement and the sizes of CDs is determined. The specimen containing 0.5 H CDs (24.6 mg/g), 1.0 H CDs (25.7 mg/g) or 2.0 H (30.4 mg/g) increases the C$_{b }$ value by 14%. 19% or 41% than the blank group respectively, after 28-d exposure to the 3 mol/L NaCl solution. Thus, the smaller the sizes of CDs, the more effective the enhancement of chloride binding.
Claims.Claim: The chloride binding capacity of cement is enhanced by the addition of CDs, with smaller CD sizes leading to more effective chloride binding.
Claims.Topic: Chloride binding capacity in cement modification

Claims.text:
More importantly, our latest studies evidenced that CDs owned an excellent dispersion stability in saturated Ca(OH)$_{2 }$ solution, and could significantly augment the chloride binding capacity of cement [29,30]. In detail, the deliberately designed CDs, with rich oxygen-containing surface functional groups and a highly crystalline graphene structure, led to a substantial enhancement of 109% in chloride binding content compared to the blank group [29]. Furthermore, N-doped CDs resulted in a significant improvement of 134% in the content of chloride binding for cement pastes [30]. Hence, CDs have demonstrated an enormous potential for boosting the chloride binding behaviors of cement.

This work controllably synthesizes green CDs with three kinds of sizes, comprehensively investigates their effect on chloride binding ability of cement, and deeply discloses the underlying mechanism.
Claims.Claim: CDs significantly enhance chloride binding capacity of cement, with N-doped CDs showing a 134% improvement.
Claims.Topic: Enhancement of chloride binding in cement.

raw_query: What specific component enhances luminescence and structural properties in FAPbI$_{3}$, and through which characteristics does it achieve improved interface and defect passivation?
optimized_query: How does a specific add-on improve the luminescence and structural properties of FAPbI$_{3}$, and what characteristics contribute to its enhanced interface alignment and defect control?
groundtruth_answer: The #PTZ-CPA# improves photoluminescence and lifetime via its #molecular dipole moment# and improves defect control through #multiple functional groups#, enhancing interface and passivation.

Claims.text: The phenothiazine (PTZ) based PTZ-CPA, carrying a cyanovinyl phosphonic acid (CPA) group, forms a superwetting hole-selective underlayer that enables facile deposition of highquality FAPbI$_{3}$ thin films. Compared to a previously established carbazole-based hole-selective material (2-(3,6-dimethoxy-9 H -carbazol-9-yl)ethyl)phosphonic acid (MeO-2PACz), the crystallinity of FAPbI$_{3}$ is enhanced and the electronic defects are passivated by the PTZ-CPA more effectively, resulting in remarkable increases in photoluminescence quantum yield (four-fold) and Shockley-ReadHall lifetime (eight-fold).
Claims.Claim: PTZ-CPA, a phenothiazine derivative, enhances the crystallinity and passivates defects in FAPbI$_{3}$ thin films more effectively than MeO-2PACz, leading to significant improvements in photoluminescence quantum yield and Shockley-Read-Hall lifetime.
Claims.Topic: Enhanced Crystallinity and Defect Passivation in FAPbI$_{3}$ Thin Films

Claims.text: The PTZ based PTZ-CPA, carrying a cyanovinyl phosphonic acid (CPA) group, forms a superwetting holeselective underlayer that enables facile deposition of high-quality FAPbI$_{3}$ thin films. Compared to MeO-2PACz, the crystallinity of FAPbI$_{3}$ is enhanced and the electronic defects are more efficiently passivated by the PTZ-CPA, resulting in remarkable increases in photoluminescence quantum yield (PLQY, four-fold) and Shockley-Read-Hall (SRH) lifetime (eight-fold). Moreover, the PTZ-CPA shows a larger molecular dipole moment and improved energy level alignment with FAPbI$_{3}$, benefiting the interfacial hole-collection.
Claims.Claim: PTZ-CPA enhances crystallinity and passivates defects in FAPbI$_{3}$ thin films, leading to increased PLQY and SRH lifetime.
Claims.Topic: Perovskite thin film enhancement

Claims.text:
Three possible reasons are proposed for the suppressed non-radiative recombination by PTZ-CPA: first, the higher wetting character of PTZ-CPA improves perovskite crystallinity and interfacial contact; second, the PTZ-CPA with multiple functional groups (phosphonic acid, cyano group and sulfur atom) passivates the defects at the buried interface and the bulk of FAPbI$_{3}$ perovskite more effectively; and third, the optimized energy level alignment between PTZ-CPA and FAPbI$_{3}$ perovskite.

Proton nuclear magnetic resonance ($^{1}$H NMR) and XPS measurements were performed to identify the molecular interactions.
Claims.Claim: PTZ-CPA suppresses non-radiative recombination in FAPbI$_{3}$ perovskite through improved crystallinity, effective defect passivation, and optimized energy level alignment.
Claims.Topic: Suppressed non-radiative recombination in perovskite materials

raw_query: What is the numerical increase in hydrogen evolution under simulated sunlight for a ternary composite, and which materials play crucial roles in enhancing its performance and stability, despite having moderate rates compared to others?
optimized_query: What improvement is observed in hydrogen evolution under simulated sunlight for a specific ternary composite, which components enhance its overall functionality, and how does its performance compare to similar materials?
groundtruth_answer: The composite shows a #99.8-fold# improvement in hydrogen evolution under sunlight; components #Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$# and #Au# crucially enhance its functionality, though its rates are still #moderate# compared to similar composites.

Claims.text:
## 4. CONCLUSIONS

The ternary composite Au/Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/CN-150 was designed and fabricated, and its photocatalytic hydrogen evolution rates under UV, simulated sunlight, and visible illumination were improved by 2.1-, 99.8-, and ∞ -fold, respectively, relative to unmodified g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$. This is a huge enhancement compared to other Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ photocatalysts of similar composition reported in the literature, which is mainly attributed to the spatial separation of photogenerated charges by Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$ acting as a bridge between modified g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ and Au particles, the multifunctional property of Au.
Claims.Claim: The ternary composite Au/Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/CN-150 demonstrates significantly enhanced photocatalytic hydrogen evolution rates under various light conditions, outperforming unmodified g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ and other similar Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ photocatalysts, due to the effective spatial separation of photogenerated charges by Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$ acting as a bridge and the multifunctional property of Au.
Claims.Topic: Enhanced Photocatalytic Hydrogen Evolution Rates

Claims.text: The role of Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$ in assisting electron transfer in the composites and the role of Au in enhancing photocatalytic performance and photocatalytic stability are highlighted here. Such new synergistic effects in the Au/Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/CN-150 composite photocatalyst are supported by photoelectrochemical tests, DFT calculations, and photocatalytic control experiments. Moreover, this ternary composite photocatalyst exhibits excellent sustained hydrogen evolution performance. Our work provides a practical strategy to enhance the visible light photocatalytic activity and improve the photostability of the MXene-containing photocatalyst. However, the complexity of the preparation process of this composite photocatalyst and the need for further simplification of the synthesis as well as its photostability still have room for improvement, and subsequent work can be devoted to solving these problems.
Claims.Claim: The Au/Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/CN-150 composite photocatalyst exhibits excellent sustained hydrogen evolution performance due to the synergistic effects of Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$ in assisting electron transfer and Au in enhancing photocatalytic performance and stability, supported by various tests and calculations.
Claims.Topic: Enhancing visible light photocatalytic activity and photostability of MXene-containing photocatalyst

Claims.text:
Based on the results of the high enhancement multiplier of Au/Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/CN-150 relative to the photocatalytic performance of g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$, we can conclude that the strategy of integrating Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$, Au, and CN-150 into a composite photocatalyst is successful and excellent. It should also be noted that the absolute values of the hydrogen evolution rates and the AQY@ 420 nm of the photocatalysts in this paper are still moderate compared with those of similar composites, which indicates that subsequent studies can be deepened in the preparation of g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ and Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$ to further enhance the photocatalytic activity.

3.5. Photocatalytic Mechanism.

Claims.Topic: Enhancement of photocatalytic performance

Claims.text:
Due to its magnetic-responsive properties and photothermal conversion capabilities, the PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel autonomously absorbs oil under magnetic control, enabling its effective deployment in the treatment of high-viscosity oils and facilitating separation and recovery process. Meanwhile, continuous oil/water separation was achieved through gravity or with the assistance of a peristaltic pump. In addition, various kinds of emerging pollutants, especially MPs, were efficiently captured from the aqueous solution using the PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel. As a result, the sustainable PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel is considered an appealing option for large-scale purification of wastewater.

raw_query: What modification leads to improved oxygen reduction reactions by altering both bond adsorption of a specific intermediate and the electronic configuration of active sites?
optimized_query: How do Mn clusters affect the adsorption of intermediates, the electronic structure of active sites, and the overall performance in oxygen reduction reactions?
groundtruth_answer: Mn clusters reduce #adsorption of OH*#, alter #electron configuration#, and improve #ORR performance# by lowering the reaction energy barrier and modifying geometric structures.

Claims.text:
The introduction of Mn clusters broke the planar structure of Mn$_{2}$-N$_{6 }$through axial traction, further altering the electron configuration around the active sites and effectively decreasing the adsorption strength of oxygen-containing intermediates and reaction energy barriers, leading to increased intrinsic activity, which greatly improved the ORR performance (E$_{1/2 }$ = 0.91 V). This work presented a novel way of regulating the electronic structure of homonuclear double single-atom sites by clusters.

## 1.
Claims.Claim: The introduction of Mn clusters alters the electron configuration around active sites, decreasing adsorption strength of oxygen-containing intermediates and reaction energy barriers, thereby increasing intrinsic activity and improving ORR performance.
Claims.Topic: Regulation of electronic structure in homonuclear double single-atom sites

Claims.text: After Mn clusters were introduced, due to the decrease in the adsorption of OH*, the reaction energy barrier in this step decreased, thereby accelerating the ORR. Schematic diagrams (Fig. 1g and Fig. S6 -9) of the dynamic changes in the bond lengths of OOH*, O*, and OH* in the ORR pathway for Mn$_{SAC}$-N-C, Mn$_{cluster}$/Mn$_{SAC}$-N-C, Mn$_{DAC}$N-C, and Mn$_{cluster}$/Mn$_{DAC}$-N-C were calculated separately, and the change in free energy in each step of the ORR at 0 V was recorded.
Claims.Claim: Introduction of Mn clusters decreases adsorption of OH*, reducing reaction energy barrier and accelerating the ORR.
Claims.Topic: Acceleration of ORR through decreased OH* adsorption

Claims.text: The DFT calculations showed that Mn$_{2}$-N$_{6 }$axially pulled by Mn clusters was the main active site, which presented a strong adsorption capacity for O$_{2}$, and could rapidly capture O$_{2 }$during the ORR process. The Mn clusters can further modify the electronic distribution and geometric structure of Mn$_{2}$-N$_{6}$. This process reduced the adsorption strength of the oxygencontaining intermediate at the active site and lowered the reaction energy barrier of the determining-rate step, thus enhancing the ORR performance. The Mn$_{cluster}$/Mn$_{DAC}$-N-C catalyst exhibited excellent ORR performance under alkaline conditions (E$_{1/2 }$ = 0.91 V), which was greater than that of commercial Pt/C (0.86 V).
Claims.Claim: Mn clusters enhance the ORR performance of Mn$_{2}$-N$_{6}$ by modifying its electronic distribution and geometric structure, reducing the adsorption strength of oxygen-containing intermediates and lowering the reaction energy barrier.
Claims.Topic: Enhancement of ORR performance by Mn clusters

Claims.text: Notably, the CZO piezocatalyst maintains its H$_{2}$O$_{2}$ generation capability even after multiple cycles, showing continuous improvement (from 1.3 mM to 1.8 mM). Moreover, the CZO piezocatalysts maintain outstanding performance in pollutant degradation and H$_{2}$O$_{2}$ production even after long periods of inactivity, and the deactivated catalyst due to metal ion dissolution could be rejuvenated by pH adjustment, offering a sustainable solution for wastewater purification.

Claims.text:
According to our previous work, the morphology of the perovskite near the bottom interface plays an important role in affecting optoelectronic properties of perovskite and device performance.$^{[14]}$ We peeled off the perovskite films with an epoxy

encapsulant and carefully characterized the morphology of the exposed bottom surface. Both of the two bottom surfaces showed compact and homogeneous morphology without observable voids or pinholes (Figure 2f). The bottom surface of PTZ-CPA based FAPbI$_{3}$ perovskite films exhibited enlarged grain size. These results suggest that the use of PTZ-CPA as HTL substantially improves the FAPbI$_{3}$ perovskite film quality, which could benefit solar cell performance through minimized interfacial non-radiative recombination.
Claims.Claim: The use of PTZ-CPA as HTL substantially improves the FAPbI$_{3}$ perovskite film quality, which could benefit solar cell performance through minimized interfacial non-radiative recombination.
Claims.Topic: The role of perovskite morphology in optoelectronic properties and device performance

These devices show decent photovoltaic performance (Figure S28 and Table S6), suggesting a broad application potential of this new molecular hole-transporter.
Claims.Claim: PTZ-CPA as HTL enhances photovoltaic performance in various perovskite compositions.
Claims.Topic: Molecular hole-transporter for perovskite solar cells

amphiphilicity of the CPA-based PTZ-CPA and its bilayer stacking on the ITO substrates, i.e. a chemically anchored monolayer plus an unadsorbed overlayer as revealed in our previous work. Claims.text:
## ABSTRACT

A series of Tb 3 + substituted layered perovskite Sr(La$_{1-}$$_{x}$Tb$_{x}$)AlO$_{4 }$ ( x = 0 -1) was synthesized via solid-state reaction. The influence of Tb 3 + on the phase, structure, photoluminescence, and long afterglow properties of the SrLaAlO$_{4 }$product was investigated. The fully substituted product SrTbAlO$_{4 }$was found to be isostructural with its SrLaAlO$_{4 }$counterpart, and the crystal structure parameters were first reported in this work.
Claims.Claim: Tb^3+ substitution in SrLaAlO4 influences its phase, structure, photoluminescence, and long afterglow properties.
Claims.Topic: Tb^3+ substitution in layered perovskite SrLaAlO4

Claims.text:
Aluminates have excellent chemical and thermal stability, and layered perovskites aluminates SrLaAlO$_{4 }$ have extra advantages of environmental friendliness and cheap raw materials. Therefore, in this work, SrLaAlO$_{4 }$ was selected as the host for the design of photoluminescence and long afterglow material. A series of Tb 3 + substituted SrLaAlO$_{4 }$materials were prepared by solid-state reaction. The influence of Tb 3 + substitution on the phase, crystal structure, photoluminescence, and long afterglow properties of SrLaAlO$_{4 }$were systematically investigated. The luminescence mechanism was proposed. We believe this work is important for studying the long afterglow luminescence of layered perovskites.

## 2.

When the UV light source is turned off, the afterglow luminescence of SrLaAlO$_{4}$: 0.03 Tb 3 + can last over 1 h. The trap distribution of SrLaAlO$_{4}$: Tb 3 + was analyzed in detail by thermoluminescence. The trap depth is calculated to be around 0.7 -0.81 eV, the value of which highly coincides with the ideal energy level for trapping and releasing electrons at room temperature.

groundtruth_answer: The sample #Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3# has the lowest #Tafel slope# for #ORR#, the smallest #Tafel slope# for #OER#, and exhibits remarkable #bifunctional electrocatalytic performance#.

Claims.text: Among all the prepared samples, Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3 had the lowest Tafel slope (88.1 mV dec - $^{1}$), followed by Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.1 (90.9 mV dec - $^{1}$) and Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.5 (94.3 mV dec - $^{1}$) (Fig. 4b and Table S1 † ). Claims.Topic: ORR reaction kinetics improvement

Claims.text: Notably, Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3 has the highest OER activity, meaning that the balance between the alloy and SSA is useful for improving the OER performance. Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3 has the smallest Tafel slope (87.7 mV dec - $^{1}$) among all samples, which con  rms that the OER of the catalyst is optimized when the amount of FeCo alloy in the Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3 sample is in equilibrium with the speci  c surface area (Fig. 4f).

Claims.text: It is expected that the Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3 catalyst has excellent ORR and OER activities for the following reasons: (1) the FeCo alloy has high structural activity, especially for the OER; (2) the FeCo alloy has a strong synergistic effect with the carbon skeleton, which can optimize the electronic structure; (3) the balance between the number of FeCo alloy nanoparticles and the pore volume of the material can increase the density and exposure of the active sites. In fact, Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3 displays extraordinary bifunctional electrocatalytic performance with a small D E of 0.686 V, which was better than the value reported in lots of studies.
Claims.Claim: The Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3 catalyst exhibits excellent ORR and OER activities due to the structural activity and synergistic effect of the FeCo alloy with the carbon skeleton, and the optimized balance between the number of FeCo alloy nanoparticles and the pore volume of the material.
Claims.Topic: Bifunctional electrocatalytic performance for ORR and OER

raw_query: What is used to develop an integrated setup for detecting organophosphates based on its enzyme-mimicking activity and how does it alter visual characteristics in this process?
optimized_query: What material is used to create an integrated platform for multi-mode detection of organophosphates, and what catalytic activity results in specific absorption features during this process?
groundtruth_answer: #Manganese modified porphyrin MOF# is used for a #multimode detection platform#, utilizing its #catalytic oxidation#, which produces #specific absorption peaks#.

Claims.text:
## ABSTRACT

Herein, a novel dual-mode probe for organophosphorus pesticides (OPs) colorimetric and photothermal detection was developed based on manganese modified porphyrin metal -organic framework (PCN-224-Mn). PCN-224Mn had excellent oxidase-like activity and oxidized colorless 3,3,5,5-tetramethylbenzidine (TMB) to blue -green oxidation state TMB (oxTMB), which exhibited high temperature under near-infrared irradiation. L-ascorbate-2phosphate was hydrolyzed by acid phosphatase to produce ascorbic acid, which weakened colorimetric and photothermal signals by impacting oxTMB generation.
Claims.Claim: PCN-224-Mn MOF exhibits oxidase-like activity and generates a photothermal effect, enabling its use as a dual-mode probe for detecting organophosphorus pesticides.
Claims.Topic: Dual-mode detection of organophosphorus pesticides

Claims.text:
Inspired by this, the development of an integrated platform for colorimetric and

photothermal reading is expected to achieve visual, portable, and highly sensitive multimode detection of OPs.

Enlightened by the aforementioned work, this study prepared a novel MOF-based nanozyme (PCN-224-Mn) with excellent oxidase-like catalytic activity by coordinating Mn (II) to the porphyrin cavity of PCN-224 composed of zirconium (Zr) clusters and porphyrin ligands. A dual-mode probe for OPs colorimetric and photothermal detection was developed based on the catalytic activity, the competition effect between enzymatic reaction products and substrates, the inhibition of OPs on enzyme activity, and photothermal effect of oxidation products.
Claims.Claim: PCN-224-Mn MOF-based nanozyme enables dual-mode probe for OPs colorimetric and photothermal detection.
Claims.Topic: Multimode detection of organophosphates (OPs)

Claims.text:
## 3.2. Evaluation of oxidase-like activity

As shown in Fig. 2A, neither the TMB solution nor the PCN-224-Mn solution exhibited characteristic absorption peaks in the range of 500 ~ 700 nm. However, when PCN-224-Mn coexisted with TMB, an obvious absorption peak appeared at 652 nm, which was because oxTMB was produced by the catalytic oxidation of PCN-224-Mn to TMB. In addition to TMB, PCN-224-Mn can also catalyze other substrates including OPD and ABTS. As shown in Fig. 2B, in the presence of PCN-224-Mn, the OPD solution and the ABTS solution exhibited obvious absorption peaks at 450 nm and 400 nm. The solutions appeared yellow and blue in daylight, respectively.
Claims.Claim: PCN-224-Mn exhibits oxidase-like activity by catalyzing the oxidation of substrates such as TMB, OPD, and ABTS, resulting in characteristic absorption peaks at specific wavelengths.
Claims.Topic: Oxidase-like activity of PCN-224-Mn

raw_query: What interactions and conversions, observed through specific chemical groups' coordination and participation, stabilize the protective film on zinc during its interface regulation process?

groundtruth_answer: The stability of the SEI is achieved by #Gln# modifying surface absorption, involving strong #coordination# with N/O groups, leading to #C=O# transforming to #C-O#.

Claims.text: The theoretical calculations and experiments reveal that Gln molecules can effectively regulate the surface absorption environment of the EDL, resulting in a SEI composed of organic Gln and inorganic ZnS components. The SEI exhibits low modulus and hardness properties, which contribute to its exceptional topological adaptability and compatibility with the zinc anode. This allows it to maintain co-type contact with the zinc anode while inhibiting side reactions, thereby providing lasting protection for the zinc anode ( Figure 1 b).
Claims.Claim: Gln molecules regulate the surface absorption environment of the EDL, forming a SEI with organic Gln and inorganic ZnS components, which exhibits low modulus and hardness properties, contributing to its exceptional topological adaptability and compatibility with the zinc anode, maintaining co-type contact while inhibiting side reactions, providing lasting protection for the zinc anode.
Claims.Topic: Gln-regulated SEI for Zinc Anode Protection

Claims.text:
11 , 20 Moreover, the peaks observed in the high-resolution N 1s and Zn 2p XPS spectra ( Figure 2 f,g) provide evidence for the formation of N  Zn/O  Zn bonds between Gln and the Zn surface through amino and carbonyl groups containing nitrogen and oxygen. 11 , 20 , 21 These facts further prove that Gln tightly adsorbs onto the Zn surface through strong coordination and electrostatic interactions between the zinc surface and amino or carbonyl groups. The above analysis shows that the additive can tightly adsorb onto the zinc surface, regulating the EDL structure and creating an optimal environment for stable SEI generation.

We further employed the ion conductivity to investigate the impact of Gln additives on the fundamental properties of electrolytes ( Figure S6 ).
Claims.Claim: Gln tightly adsorbs onto the Zn surface through strong coordination and electrostatic interactions between the zinc surface and amino or carbonyl groups, regulating the EDL structure and creating an optimal environment for stable SEI generation.
Claims.Topic: Adsorption of Gln onto Zinc Surface for Stable SEI Generation

Claims.text:
Consequently, this leads to the development of a stable SEI film.

To further validate the impact of Gln on SEI formation, XPS depth profiles of Zn anodes were acquired after 20 cycles at a current density of 1 mA cm - 2 and a capacity of 1 mA h cm - 2 in a Zn//Zn symmetric cell. The C 1s spectrum ( Figure 4 g) reveals that there is no significant presence of a C  O signal in the pristine state of the zinc anode, as observed when compared to the signal from pristine Gln. However, a

noticeable increase in the C  O signal is observed, indicating the conversion of a fraction of the C  O group into a C  O bond upon interaction with the Zn surface.
Claims.Claim: Gln facilitates the formation of a stable Solid Electrolyte Interphase (SEI) film on Zn anodes.
Claims.Topic: Solid Electrolyte Interphase (SEI) Formation on Zn Anodes

raw_query: What is the theoretical voltage for a reaction that offers significant energy savings over the oxygen evolution reaction and its operational value at a specific current density?
optimized_query: What are both the theoretical and operational voltages for the urea oxidation reaction compared to the oxygen evolution reaction at a current density of 10 mA/cm²?
groundtruth_answer: The #UOR theoretical voltage# is #0.37 V vs RHE#, saving energy compared to OER. At #10 mA/cm²#, the UOR operates at #1.28 V#.

Claims.text:
## 1. Introduction

The development of highly efficient and durable electrocatalysts for accelerated urea kinetics and a reduced energy barrier is deemed imperative, urgently desired to facilitate widespread adoption.[1] An energetic advantage is exhibited by the urea oxidation reaction (UOR), boasting a low thermodynamic equilibrium potential (0.37 V versus the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE)), notably lower than the conventional oxygen evolution reaction (OER) at 1.23 V. This results in a remarkable 70% theoretical energy saving, positioning it as a promising alternative to the OER for sustainable hydrogen generation.
Claims.Claim: The urea oxidation reaction (UOR) exhibits an energetic advantage over the conventional oxygen evolution reaction (OER), offering a remarkable 70% theoretical energy saving, making it a promising alternative for sustainable hydrogen generation.
Claims.Topic: Efficient and Durable Electrocatalysts for Accelerated Urea Kinetics

Claims.text: Renewable hydrogen energy has been widely concerned and applied in practical production, and water splitting for H$_{2 }$generation is one of the greenest, high-yield and most promising hydrogen production methods among various hydrogen production methods [11 -14]. What is noteworthy is that the oxygen evolution reaction (OER), as the half-reaction of water electrolysis, requires complex four-electron transfer and is a slow step in the entire electrochemical process [15 -17]. Considering the low availability of pure water, it is found that the urea oxidation reaction (UOR) requires only the small theoretical voltage (0.37 V vs RHE), which is much lower than the 1.23 V of OER (vs RHE) [18 -20].
Claims.Claim: The urea oxidation reaction (UOR) requires only a small theoretical voltage (0.37 V vs RHE), which is much lower than the 1.23 V of the oxygen evolution reaction (OER).
Claims.Topic: Renewable Hydrogen Energy Production

Claims.text:
## 3.3. Urea oxidation catalysis

At the end of the OER and HER tests, an additional urea oxidation test (UOR) was performed with a complete electrochemical test in 1 M KOH + 0.5 M urea solution. As can be seen in the LSV plot (Fig. 5a), the target catalyst clearly outperforms the remaining catalysts throughout the operating voltage. At a current density of 10 mA/cm$^{2}$, the working potential is only 1.28 V, in which it can be observed that the performance of the CoCOH@NF precursor is not much different from the trend of Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@NF.
Claims.Claim: The target catalyst demonstrates superior performance in urea oxidation, achieving a low working potential of 1.28 V at a current density of 10 mA/cm$^{2}$ in 1 M KOH + 0.5 M urea solution.
Claims.Topic: Urea Oxidation Catalysis

raw_query: What influences are exerted by different atmospheric conditions on the initial charge capacity of Li$_{5}$FeO$_{4$, particularly in terms of changes over time and exposure outcomes?
optimized_query: How do prolonged exposures to O$_{2}$, CO$_{2}$, N$_{2}$, and air impact the first-charge capacity and material state of Li$_{5}$FeO$_{4}$?
groundtruth_answer: The first-charge capacity of #Li$_{5}$FeO$_{4}# declines significantly in #O$_{2}$# and #CO$_{2}$#; remains stable in #N$_{2}$#; air exposure causes #slurry gelation#.

Claims.text: As the samples were exposed to the O$_{2}$ atmosphere for 3, 6, 12, and 24 h, the first-charge specific capacity of Li$_{5}$FeO$_{4}$ decreased rapidly from 681.5 to 271.4, 187.5, 170.0, and 163.9 mAh g - $^{1}$, which correspond to the attenuation rate of 60.2%, 72.5%, and 75.1% and 75.9%, respectively. The decay of the first-charge capacity approached the limit by increasing the exposure time, indicating that there is a time threshold for oxygen influence.
Claims.Claim: The first-charge specific capacity of Li$_{5}$FeO$_{4}$ decreases rapidly when exposed to O$_{2}$ atmosphere, with the decay approaching a limit, indicating a time threshold for oxygen influence.
Claims.Topic: Influence of Oxygen Exposure on the First-Charge Specific Capacity of Li$_{5}$FeO$_{4}$

Claims.text: Li$_{5}$FeO$_{4}$ was then subjected to the CO$_{2}$ atmosphere for 3, 6, 12, and 24 h as seen in Figure 4b. The first chargespecific capacity of Li$_{5}$FeO$_{4}$ decreased from 681.5 to 204.6, 129.8, 82.3, and 50.3 mAh g - $^{1}$, corresponding to decay ratios of 69.9%, 80.9%, 87.9% and 92.6%, respectively. The first charge capacity of the material gradually decays with increasing exposure time.
Claims.Claim: The first charge-specific capacity of Li$_{5}$FeO$_{4}$ decreases with increasing exposure time to CO$_{2}$, leading to decay ratios of 69.9%, 80.9%, 87.9%, and 92.6% after 3, 6, 12, and 24 hours, respectively.
Claims.Topic: Effect of CO$_{2}$ exposure on the charge-specific capacity of Li$_{5}$FeO$_{4}$

Claims.text: The first charge capacity of the material gradually decays with increasing exposure time. In Figure S7 (Supporting Information), the first charge-specific capacities of Li$_{5}$FeO$_{4}$ after 3, 6, 12, and 24 h in the N$_{2}$ atmosphere were nearly the same. It supports that N$_{2}$ has almost no effect on the performance of Li$_{5}$FeO$_{4}$. However, LFO exposure to air for 24 h produced significant slurry gelation compared to those not exposed to air, as shown in Figure S8 (Supporting Information). Hence, the electrochemical properties of LFO exposed to air were not performed.
Claims.Claim: The first charge-specific capacities of Li$_{5}$FeO$_{4}$ after 3, 6, 12, and 24 h in the N$_{2}$ atmosphere were nearly the same, supporting that N$_{2}$ has almost no effect on the performance of Li$_{5}$FeO$_{4}$.
Claims.Topic: Effect of N$_{2}$ atmosphere on the performance of Li$_{5}$FeO$_{4}$

raw_query: What materials demonstrate efficient hydrogen production and catalytic activity in different environments?
optimized_query: Which catalysts are used in urea electrolysis for hydrogen evolution and exhibit catalytic efficiency in alkaline conditions?
groundtruth_answer: #Mo$_{3}$P@NiCoP/NF# facilitates #H$_{2}$ generation# in urea electrolysis; #Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@CoP# shows robust catalytic #activity in alkaline# environments.

Claims.text:
## ABSTRACT

Urea electrolysis is an effective way to replace water splitting for H$_{2 }$generation, which is expected to achieve carbon neutralization. However, problems such as high energy consumption and slow urea oxidation kinetics have hindered its rapid development. In this study, a series of foreign element modified NiCoP-based catalysts were in-situ grown on Ni foam through hydrothermal process, solvothermal method and low temperature phosphating method. The morphology of the electrode was regulated by changing the impregnation elements. It was found that Mo$_{3}$P@NiCoP/NF has rich active sites and small impedance, which makes it have excellent urea oxidation reaction (UOR) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) property.

raw_query: What substance alters the interface to improve longevity and capacity by enhancing its adaptability and mechanical property within zinc-ion batteries?
optimized_query: What additive is used to modify the SEI in zinc-ion batteries to improve both its mechanical flexibility and enhance battery cycle life and capacity?
groundtruth_answer: #L-glutamine# modifies SEI, enhancing its #flexibility#, leading to improved #cycle life# and #capacity# in zinc-ion batteries.

Claims.text:
In this study, we introduce L-glutamine (Gln) as an additive to regulate the adsorbed environment of the EDL and in situ produce a hybrid SEI consisting of ZnS and Gln-related species. The results of the nanoindentation test indicate that the hybrid SEI exhibits

Supporting Information

a low modulus and low hardness, alongside exceptional shape recovery capability, which effectively limits side reactions and enables topological adaptation to volume fluctuations in zinc anodes during zinc ion plating/stripping, thereby enabling Zn// Zn symmetric cells to exhibit an ultralong cycle life of 4000 h in coin cells and a high cumulative capacity of 18,000 mA h in pouch cells.
Claims.Claim: The hybrid SEI consisting of ZnS and Gln-related species effectively limits side reactions and enables topological adaptation to volume fluctuations in zinc anodes during zinc ion plating/stripping, thereby enabling Zn// Zn symmetric cells to exhibit an ultralong cycle life of 4000 h in coin cells and a high cumulative capacity of 18,000 mA h in pouch cells.
Claims.Topic: Regulation of the adsorbed environment of the EDL (Electrical Double Layer) in zinc-ion batteries with L-glutamine (Gln) as an additive.

Claims.text: The topologically adaptable solid electrolyte interface (SEI) effectively suppresses side reactions and accommodates volume changes in the zinc anode during zinc ion plating/ stripping, enabling Zn//Zn symmetric cells to demonstrate an exceptionally long cycle life of 4000/1600/1200/300 h at a current density of 1/5/10/20 mA cm - 2 using a coin cell. Additionally, it achieves a high cumulative capacity of 18,000 mA h with a pouch cell. More importantly, the Gln additives have also been demonstrated in Zn//NH$_{4}$V$_{4}$O$_{10}$ full cells at low N/P ratios of 5.2, 4.9, 3.5, and 2.4, which further proves the effectiveness of Gln additive for Zn anode protection.
Claims.Claim: The topologically adaptable solid electrolyte interface (SEI) effectively suppresses side reactions and accommodates volume changes in the zinc anode during zinc ion plating/stripping, enabling Zn//Zn symmetric cells to demonstrate an exceptionally long cycle life and high cumulative capacity.
Claims.Topic: Zinc Anode Protection in Zinc-Ion Batteries

Claims.text: This observation suggests that the SEI formed in the ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte exhibits limited resistance to deformation and fails to maintain intimate contact with the zinc anode during plating/stripping cycles, rendering it susceptible to rupture. In contrast, the SEI formed in Gln/ZnSO$_{4}$ demonstrates flexibility, enabling it to accommodate volume changes and consistently establish co-type contact with the zinc anode for continuous and stable protection. In addition, hardness is also an indicator to prove the mechanical properties of materials. 30 As depicted in Figure S14b and Figure 4 l, the hardness of the SEI in the ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte exhibits a significantly higher value compared to that formed in the Gln/ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte.
Claims.Claim: The SEI formed in Gln/ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte demonstrates flexibility, enabling it to accommodate volume changes and consistently establish co-type contact with the zinc anode for continuous and stable protection.

Claims.text: Electrochemical Measurements. All testing CR2032-type coin cells were assembled in an open-air environment by using a glass fiber filter (GF/D, Whatman) as the separator. The electrolyte amount used in coin cells was 100 μ L. Zn//Zn symmetric cells were fabricated by using two identical Zn foils (100 μ m). Zn//Cu asymmetric cells were assembled with Cu foil (30 μ m) as the working electrode and Zn foil (100 μ m) as the reference and counter electrode. Zn//NH$_{4}$V$_{4}$O$_{10}$ full cells were assembled using Zn foil (20 μ m) as the anode and NH$_{4}$V$_{4}$O$_{10}$ as the cathode.

The discharge/charge measurements of cells were conducted using a LAND Cell Test System. CV curves of the Zn plating/stripping were measured using the Zn//Cu coin cell at a scan rate of 1 mV s - $^{1}$. EIS were recorded with a frequency ranging from 0.1 to 10 6 Hz.

To further enhance zinc utilization and minimize unnecessary zinc loss, we used a thin Zn anode (20 μ m) to investigate Zn//NH$_{4}$V$_{4}$O$_{10}$ full cells with a low negative/ positive capacity ratio (N/P) ( Figure 6 c - f and Figures S18 and S19 ). The cycling performance of the full cells with a N/P ratio of 4.9 is shown in Figure 6 c. The cell in the ZnSO$_{4}$

electrolyte survives for 1640 cycles at 5 A g - 1 before failure, while the cell in the Gln/ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte exhibits stable cycling over 4500 cycles with a high capacity retention of up to 87% (after 100 cycles of activation).

raw_query: What method is used to enhance the volumetric performance of ultramicroporous carbons through specific elemental co-modification, resulting in a capacitance achievement of a specific value?
optimized_query: What co-modification technique, involving a templating method, is used to achieve a specific volumetric capacitance in ultramicroporous carbons?
groundtruth_answer: The #boric acid# templating technique achieves #boron# and oxygen co-modification, resulting in a volumetric capacitance of #431 F cm$^{3}$.#

Claims.text:
## ABSTRACT

Carbon-based supercapacitors have shown great promise for miniaturized electronics and electric vehicles, but are usually limited by their low volumetric performance, which is largely due to the inefficient utilization of carbon pores in charge storage. Herein, we develop a reliable and scalable boric acid templating technique to prepare boron and oxygen co-modified highly-dense yet ultramicroporous carbons (BUMCs).
Claims.Claim: Boron and oxygen co-modified highly-dense yet ultramicroporous carbons (BUMCs) prepared using a boric acid templating technique show promise for enhancing the volumetric performance of carbon-based supercapacitors.
Claims.Topic: Enhancing Volumetric Performance of Carbon-Based Supercapacitors

Claims.text:
## 4. Conclusions

In summary, we prepared highly-dense yet ultramicroporous carbons with boron/oxygen-enriched surface functionalities by using a unique boric acid templating technique, where the boric acid not only acts as molecular-scale template for the formation of ultramicropores but also serves as in-situ modifier for implantation of profitable functional groups. The addition of ammonia is crucial for the esterification reaction between boric acid and glucose, which lays the foundation for homogeneously implanting of borate ester species into the crosslinked precursor of borated glucose. Our results demonstrated that an unprecedented high volumetric supercapacitive performance can be realized in such compact ultramicroporous carbons. Theoretical and experimental efforts reveal that B-containing groups ( -BC$_{2}$O and -BCO$_{2 }$ etc.)
Claims.Claim: Highly-dense yet ultramicroporous carbons with boron/oxygen-enriched surface functionalities were prepared using a unique boric acid templating technique, where boric acid acts as a molecular-scale template for the formation of ultramicropores and serves as an in-situ modifier for implanting profitable functional groups. The addition of ammonia is crucial for the esterification reaction between boric acid and glucose, which lays the foundation for homogeneously implanting borate ester species into the crosslinked precursor of borated glucose. The materials demonstrated an unprecedented high volumetric supercapacitive performance, and theoretical and experimental efforts reveal that B-containing groups play a significant role in this performance.
Claims.Topic: Boric acid templating technique for high-performance supercapacitors

Claims.text: The carbons are featured with high density (up to 1.62 g cm GLYPH<0> $^{3}$), large specific surface area (up to 1050 m$^{2 }$g GLYPH<0> $^{1}$), narrow pore distribution (0.4 -0.6 nm) and exquisite pore surface functionalities (mainly -BC$_{2}$O, GLYPH<0> BCO$_{2}$, and -COH groups). Consequently, the carbons show exceptionally compact capacitive energy storage. The optimal BUMC-0.5 delivers an outstanding volumetric capacitance of 431 F cm GLYPH<0> 3 and a high-rate capability in 1 M H$_{2}$SO$_{4}$.
Claims.Claim: The carbons exhibit exceptionally compact capacitive energy storage due to their high density, large specific surface area, narrow pore distribution, and exquisite pore surface functionalities, resulting in an outstanding volumetric capacitance of 431 F cm^-3 for the optimal BUMC-0.5 in 1 M H2SO4.
Claims.Topic: Compact Capacitive Energy Storage

4g). In addition, the value of E$_{j}$$_{=}$$_{10}$ for Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3 slightly changed a  er 1000 cycles of CV tests (Fig. S7 † ). The reasons for the enhancement of the bifunctional activity of Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3 include: (1) the FeCo alloy has high structural activity; (2) the strong synergistic effect between the FeCo alloy and carbon skeleton can optimize the electronic structure; (3) the balance between the number of FeCo alloy nanoparticles and the pore volume of the material can increase the density and exposure of the active sites.

## 4. Conclusions

In summary, a bifunctional alloy catalyst has been fabricated by encapsulating FeCo alloy nanoparticles into porous hollow carbon cages (Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3).

## 2. Material and methods

## 2.1. Synthesis of ionic liquids

4-Amino-1-butyl-1,2,4-triazolium bromide (AC$_{4}$trimBr) was obtained by using a slightly modified the literature procedure [36]. A mixture of 4-amino-1,2,4-triazole (10 mmol, 840.4 mg) and 1-bromobutane (10 mmol, 1370.2 mg) was refluxed in acetonitrile (20 mL) for 3 days. The solution was concentrated and added to excess cold ethyl acetate (3 -5 times the volume of solution) for recrystallization.

The solution was concentrated and added to excess cold ethyl acetate (3 -5 times the volume of solution) for recrystallization. 1-Butyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide (BmimBr) was synthesized according to the literature procedure with modifications. To a solution of 1-methylimidazole (10 mmol, 821.1 mg) in acetonitrile (20 mL), 1bromobutane (10 mmol, 1370.1 mg) was added. The solution was stirred and refluxed for 3 days. The solution was concentrated and added to excess cold ethyl acetate (3 -5 times the volume of solution) for recrystallization. After filtering the solvent, remove any residual solvent under vacuum to obtain colorless powders (2126 mg, 97 % of yield).
Claims.Claim: 1-Butyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide (BmimBr) was synthesized with a 97% yield, resulting in colorless powders after recrystallization and removal of residual solvent under vacuum.
Claims.Topic: Synthesis and purification of 1-Butyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide (BmimBr)

raw_query: What specific group possesses the maximal binding characteristics, and how does size influence the binding enhancement process in cement?
optimized_query: Which group demonstrates the highest chloride ion binding capacity, and what role does particle size play in the mechanisms enhancing this binding in cement?
groundtruth_answer: The #2.0 H group# shows the highest chloride ion binding capacity. The #nucleation effect# and smaller #CDs sizes# significantly enhance cement's physical adsorption and chemical binding processes.

Claims.text:
Specifically, 2.0 H group owns the highest C Fs b of 21.27 mg/g and C CSH b of 6.76 mg/g, increasing by 41.8% and 132.0% separately than C group. This evidences that CDs with the smallest size confer the strongest chloride binding capacity on cement matrices, owing to more production of C -S -H and Ms.

Furthermore, the mass loss peaks within the range of 130 -190 · C and 260 -360 · C are ascribed to the disintegration of Ms and Fs separately [58,59]. Compared to the C group, CDs-modified groups exhibit higher contents of Ms and Fs which increase as the sizes of CDs decrease. This reflects that the smaller sizes of CDs can generate more Ms to react with free chloride ions, thus improving the chemical binding of chloride ions in cement pastes.
Claims.Claim: CDs with the smallest size confer the strongest chloride binding capacity on cement matrices, owing to more production of C-S-H and Ms.
Claims.Topic: Chloride binding capacity in cement matrices

Claims.text:
8). Namely, CDs with smaller sizes can more significantly stimulate the production of C -S -H gels and Ms by their nucleation effect, thus greatly promoting the physical adsorption and chemical binding of cement pastes. On the one hand, according to the previous nucleation mechanism [61], the nucleation effect of CDs can be ascribed to the fact that the hydration products preferentially attach to CDs surface [30], since the nucleation energy on CDs surface is smaller than that in pore solution of cement. This facilitates the crystallization of hydrates. Therefore, CDs can significantly accelerate the hydration of cement. On the other hand, CDs with larger sizes possess a smaller quantity of particles under

the same dosage, consequently causing a decrease of nucleation sites.
Claims.Claim: CDs with smaller sizes significantly stimulate the production of C-S-H gels and Ms by their nucleation effect, promoting physical adsorption and chemical binding of cement pastes.
Claims.Topic: Nucleation effect in cement hydration

Claims.text:
To sum up, the investigation of XRD, DTG, and SEM from diverse specimens prior to and following 14-d immersion demonstrate that CDs with various sizes ranging from 1.73 to 12.37 nm are able to advance the cement hydration to produce more C -S -H gels and Ms, thus enhancing the physical adsorption and chemical binding of chloride ions. Crucially, the relationship between sizes of CDs and phase compositions of cement is disclosed. That is CDs with smaller sizes tend to accelerate cement hydration more strongly, thereby more remarkably enhancing chloride binding of cement system.

## 3.4. Influence mechanism of CDs sizes on chloride binding

According to the systematic analyses above, the effect mechanism of CDs sizes on chloride binding in cement is reasonably proposed (Fig. 8).

Claims.Topic: Influence of CDs size on cement hydration and chloride binding

raw_query: What factor increases iodine adsorption performance in a COF, its interaction index, and which method is applied to enhance this effect?
optimized_query: What specific factor affects iodine adsorption in a COF, how is its effectiveness quantified, and what post-modification technique is used to improve this performance?
groundtruth_answer: The increase in #local polarity# enhances adsorption; effectiveness is quantified by capacity from #1.5 to 5.2#. The enhancement uses the #ionic liquid solution process (ILSP)#.

Claims.text:
## ABSTRACT

The research on the adsorption and conversion of non-polar gases (carbon dioxide, hydrogen, iodine, etc.) has attracted global attention. Extensive work has revealed the intuitive impact of the heteroatom effect on the adsorption performance of covalent organic framework (COF) adsorbents for non-polar gases. However, more influencing factors must be studied to more precisely design and construct target-specific COF adsorbents. In this work, an underlying influencing factor, local polarity, is discovered, which is defined as the polarity of the functional moiety. Due to the substitution of strong electrophile, the electron cloud distribution of the COF framework is regulated, and the local polarity that better matches the adsorption of target electrophilic gas (iodine) has been observed.
Claims.Claim: The local polarity of functional moieties in covalent organic frameworks (COFs) can be regulated by the substitution of strong electrophiles, leading to a better match for adsorbing target electrophilic gases such as iodine.
Claims.Topic: Influence of Local Polarity on COF Adsorbents

Claims.text:
The classic COFs with benzene ring as the main building block has strong aromaticity and conjugation, resulting in uniform electron cloud distribution and no electron-rich moiety. Therefore, its affinity for electrophilic targets (such as iodine molecules) is very weak, indicating poor adsorption performance. Modifying the aromatic frameworks by strong electrophiles and changing its electron cloud distribution to enhance its local electron-rich properties should significantly improve the performance. However, for the precise construction of target-specific COFs, more influencing factors need to be identified.

In this work, we proposed an ionic liquid solution process (ILSP) strategy to post-modify the neutral covalent organic framework TpPaSO$_{3}$H (COF-H) to improve its iodine capture performance (Fig. 1).
Claims.Claim: Modifying the aromatic frameworks of COFs with strong electrophiles can enhance their local electron-rich properties, improving their performance for capturing electrophilic targets like iodine molecules.
Claims.Topic: Enhancing COF Performance for Iodine Capture

Claims.text: Through in-depth research on the COF structure, it unexpectedly discovered an underlying contribution, local polarity. The increase in local polarity led to stronger interaction between the electro-rich site and iodine, and it was observed that there was a positive correlation between local polarity and adsorption performance. The introduction of electrophile can regulate the local polarity of COF, significantly improving its adsorption performance. The saturated adsorption capacity increased from 1.5 to 5.2 g · g GLYPH<0> $^{1}$, and the adsorption kinetics index k$_{80% }$value increased from 0.51 to 2.69 g · g GLYPH<0> $^{1$_{·}$}$h GLYPH<0> $^{1}$. The discovery of contribution of local polarity will provide important fundamental guidance for the precise synthesis of COFs.
Claims.Claim: The introduction of electrophile can regulate the local polarity of COF, significantly improving its adsorption performance.
Claims.Topic: Contribution of local polarity in COF adsorption performance

In conclusion, the "interfacial spontaneous reduction" strategy was developed to construct a Pt single-atom catalyst by reducing the Pt species at the solid - liquid interface without an external reducing agent. raw_query: What factors interplay to influence the transport differences and removal strategies of chiral pharmaceuticals, especially considering their structural interactions and environmental pH?
optimized_query: Which structural characteristics and environmental factors affect chiral pharmaceutical transport and strategies for their environmental management, requiring an analysis of interactions and pH effects?
groundtruth_answer: The #enantiomeric structures# alter transport, with #environmental pH# reducing sorption differences, thereby guiding #removal strategies# for managing chiral pharmaceuticals in varied conditions.

Claims.text:
## ABSTRACT

The study examined the transport behavior of the 2-aryl propionic acid (2-APA) chiral pharmaceutical enantiomers by means of a laboratory-scale saturated quartz sand column experiment. Four typical of 2-APA and their enantiomers were selected for the study under different types of chiral organic acids (COAs)-mediated effects. Differences in the transport of the 2-APA enantiomeric pairs have been identified in response to various pH, types of COAs, and enantiomeric structures of COAs. Redundancy analysis identified the factors responsible for the largest differences in transport of 2-APA enantiomeric pairs, while spectroscopic characterization and density function theory (DFT) studies elucidated the underlying mechanisms contributing to the differences in transport of enantiomeric pairs.
Claims.Claim: The transport behavior of 2-APA chiral pharmaceutical enantiomers in saturated quartz sand columns is influenced by pH, types of chiral organic acids (COAs), and the enantiomeric structures of COAs.
Claims.Topic: Transport behavior of chiral pharmaceutical enantiomers

Claims.text:
predominant cause of the difference in affinity of 2-APA enantiomeric pairs for sand, which leads to different transport behaviour of 2-APA enantiomers. Therefore, it is necessary to evaluate the transport behavior of chiral compounds distinguishing different enantiomers in future studies. A more in-depth study focusing on the transport behavior of enantiomeric pairs under different physicochemical conditions would contribute to reveal the important chiral role of enantiomeric transport under complex environmental conditions and provide a more efficient way for the removal of chiral compounds.

## Environmental implication

Release of PhACs into natural eco-environment creates significant hazards, leading to long-term exposure of non-target organisms. Assessing the transport and fate of PhACs in environment requires consideration of the stereoselective interactions effects.
Claims.Claim: The transport behavior of chiral compounds, particularly the 2-APA enantiomers, is influenced by their affinity differences for sand, necessitating separate evaluations for each enantiomer in future studies.
Claims.Topic: Stereoselective interactions in environmental transport of chiral compounds

Claims.text:
Fig. 5. Differences in the recovery of transport of 2-aryl propionic acid chiral pharmaceutical enantiomers under different environmental conditions (a), redundancy analysis on the differences in the recovery of enantiomers by different environmental conditions (b), and graphical representation of the effect of COAs on the sorption of 2-APA enantiomers on the surface of quartz sand (c).

The difference in enrichment of 2-APA on the surface of the sand was significantly reduced when the pH was more than three. When pH is three however, COAs molecules are subjected to double electric layer (EDL) repulsion during their proximity to 2-APA enantiomer molecules, which exhibit a mutual repulsion effect.
Claims.Claim: The recovery of 2-aryl propionic acid (2-APA) chiral pharmaceutical enantiomers is significantly affected by environmental conditions, particularly pH levels, which influence the sorption behavior of these enantiomers on the surface of quartz sand.
Claims.Topic: Environmental influence on the sorption of chiral pharmaceutical enantiomers

Claims.text: It was reported that most pristine g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ modi  cation studies are concerned with the heterojunction engineering of g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ photocatalytic systems for H$_{2}$ production. 24,25 Few research studies have considered the functionalization of g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ including hydroxylation and carboxylation on a triazine structure. The effective adsorption and activation of H$_{2}$O molecules on the gC$_{3}$N$_{4}$ surface is a prerequisite for the evolution of H$_{2}$OtoH$_{2}$.
Claims.Claim: Functionalization of g-C3N4 through hydroxylation and carboxylation enhances the adsorption and activation of H2O molecules on its surface, thereby improving the evolution of H2O to H2.
Claims.Topic: Functionalization of g-C3N4 for enhanced photocatalytic H2 production

Claims.text:
Although the introduction of -OH on the surface of g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ did not destroy the morphology, photo-response activity, and triazine ring structure, the band position, carrier migration properties, and H$_{2}$ evolution markedly improved. Therefore, the C-coupled hydroxyl-g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ surface is more favorable for H$_{2}$O adsorption and H$_{2}$ escape. This work provides new insights into fabricating highly efficient and stable functionalized photocatalysts from a structural optimization perspective.

## 4. Experiment

## 4.1 Sample preparation

Pristine g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ was fabricated via the traditional thermalcondensation treatment.
Claims.Claim: The introduction of -OH on the surface of g-C3N4 improves band position, carrier migration properties, and H2 evolution, making it more favorable for H2O adsorption and H2 escape.
Claims.Topic: Surface modification of g-C3N4 for enhanced photocatalytic H2 evolution

Claims.text: Speci  cally, the lower electronegativity of the formaldehyde-treated samples was closely related to the surface gra  ed -OH. It could be inferred that the temperature and reaction time have a profound effect on the number of -OH groups on the catalyst surface, which promoted the rearrangement of the g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ surface charge and thus in  uenced the electronegativity of the samples. According to the previous analysis, the -OH groups introduced on the formaldehydetreated g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ frameworks had excellent effects on the generation, separation, and migration of the photoinduced carriers and photocatalytic performance, and further enhanced the activity of photocatalytic decomposition of water via increased H$_{2}$O adsorption capacity.
Claims.Claim: The surface-grafted -OH groups on formaldehyde-treated g-C3N4 samples significantly influence their electronegativity, promoting the rearrangement of surface charge and enhancing photocatalytic performance.

Claims.text: As a comparison, the low-valent Pt atoms dispersed on Pt$_{1}$ - N - C can directly catalyze the hydrosilylation between 1-octene and triethoxysilane without a long preactivation period, resulting in the high TOF of 4.5 × 10 5 h - 1 in the whole process, which surpassed all reported Pt heterogeneous catalysts ( Figure S25 ). The reaction even takes place at room temperature ( Figure S26 ) with a TOF of 7472 h - $^{1}$. These results suggest that the atomically dispersed and low-valent Pt provides high activity, which guarantees success in the hydrosilylation reaction under rather mild conditions.

Furthermore, the reaction using poly(methylhydrosiloxane) as a silane substrate was explored, in which each monomer unit contains a reactive H atom.

Nickel foam (3 cm*6 cm) was first cleaned by ultrasonication in ethanol and deionized water for 15 mins sequentially. 0.66 g Co(NO$_{3}$)$_{2}$ · 6H$_{2}$O, 0.178 g NH$_{4}$F and 0.72 g Co(NH$_{2}$)$_{2 }$were dissolved in 60 mL of deionized water. raw_query: What properties determine the hierarchy of reagent molecules used for lithium removal, and how does the choice of medium influence this process?

Claims.text:
Cyclic voltammograms (Fig. S1a online) of these lithiation reagents, at identical Li + concentration, indicate a redox potential sequence: Bp > Nap > P-Ter > Pyr > An > Per.

Referring to the redox reaction equation (Eq. (1)) governing lithiation reagents formation, PAHs with higher oxidative potential are theoretically prone to acquire delocalized electrons, thereby enhancing their binding with Li + and facilitating the extraction process. Subsequently, we conducted a comparative analysis of various PAHs' lithium extraction capabilities from lithiated graphite under identical conditions, detailed in the Supplementary materials (online). As expected, higher redox potential in lithiation reagents corresponds to greater extraction of lithium content (Fig. S1b online), indicating a positive correlation between these variables.
Claims.Claim: Higher oxidative potential in PAHs enhances their binding with Li+ and facilitates lithium extraction.
Claims.Topic: Lithiation reagents and their redox potential for lithium extraction

Claims.text:
Fig. 2a illustrates that in THF, the differing Li + binding affinities of Bp, Nap, and Pyr, based on their distinct redox potentials, lead to varied extraction capacities (Pyr > Nap > Bp). This order confirms that PAHs with higher redox potentials yield higher lithium concentrations.

Fig. 2b elucidates the effects of THF, 2-MeTHF, and DME. The extraction capacity increases as the solvating power decreases (DME > THF > 2-MeTHF, Fig. S3 online) [32]. Weakly solvated solvents facilitate desolvation, enhancing the coordination ability of

Fig. 1. Screening of PAHs for lithium extraction systems. (a) Molecular structures of various PAHs.
Claims.Claim: PAHs with higher redox potentials yield higher lithium concentrations.
Claims.Topic: Lithium Extraction Efficiency

Claims.text:
## 3.1. Screening principle of PAHs for lithium extraction systems

We selected a range of representative PAHs, including biphenyl (Bp), naphthalene (Nap), p -terphenyl (P-Ter), pyrene (Pyr), anthracene (An), and perylene (Per) (structures shown in Fig. 1a). The selection was guided by several factors: (1) These reagent molecules contain only benzene ring structures, excluding interference from other factors. (2) The chosen PAHs have distinct redox potentials, allowing for investigation into the relationship between their redox potentials and the reversible lithium content. (3) These reagents are cost-effective, offering practical applicability.
Claims.Claim: PAHs with distinct redox potentials are selected for lithium extraction based on their benzene ring structures, redox properties, and cost-effectiveness.
Claims.Topic: Lithium Extraction Systems

Claims.text: Specifically, the high nitrogen concentration triggers the redistribution of the coordination environment around the Mo atoms, leading to the expanded distance between valence band and Fermi level. Accordingly, the d band center is pushed down to the lower energy level, thus weaking the binding energy of produce H$_{2}$. Simultaneously, on account of the adequate and stronger N 2 p - Mo 4 d hybridization, the Mo atoms display the emptier 4 d orbital, enhancing the H$_{2}$O dissociation. Benefiting from the synergy above, the N$_{h}$-Mo$_{2}$C reveals comparable catalytic activity and stability of HER in both the alkaline and acid solution. This work presents valuable method to adjust the electronic configuration of carbide, and inspires the development of new electrocatalysts via multiscale modulation strategy.

raw_query: What enhances a composite's active performance in light-range processes through distinct roles, and what unique property do these elements display within a specific wavelength interval?

groundtruth_answer: #Au particles# improve performance by a #synergistic effect# with CN-150 and Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$, showing a #characteristic absorption peak# in the #500-650 nm range#.

Claims.text: Figure 7 c shows the results of the photocatalytic performance of the H$_{2}$ evolution of the Au/Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/CN-150 ternary composite compared with the other samples. From the observation of the variation of hydrogen evolution rates of different photocatalysts under visible illumination, it can be concluded that Au particles are the key component contributing to the visible photocatalytic performance of the composite, and the Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$ has a weak function in enhancing the generalizable light response of the parent material but improves the overall performance, particularly under visible light for the Au/Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/CN-150 ternary composite. Moreover, a bridging role of Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$ in enhancement of the photocatalytic performance can also be deduced.
Claims.Claim: Au particles are the key component contributing to the visible photocatalytic performance of the composite, and the Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$ has a weak function in enhancing the generalizable light response of the parent material but improves the overall performance, particularly under visible light for the Au/Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/CN-150 ternary composite.
Claims.Topic: Photocatalytic performance under visible light

Claims.text: At first, the basic roles of Au, CN-150, and Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$ should be clarified. There are two basic roles of Au, one is Au$_{C}$ to generate hot electrons, and the other is Au$_{T}$ to act as a photocatalytic active site. CN-150 also has two basic roles: one is that CN-150 is the main component and therefore plays the role of the carrier of the composite material, and the other role is to generate photogenerated electrons and holes by light excitation. The basic role of Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$ is to favor charge transfer due to its high electrical conductivity. When the above three components form a composite material, based on their basic roles, new roles are created, leading to the enhancement of photocatalytic performance, which is the so-called synergistic effect.
Claims.Claim: The synergistic effect of Au, CN-150, and Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$ in composite materials enhances photocatalytic performance.
Claims.Topic: Synergistic Effect in Photocatalysis

Claims.text: Compared with CN-150, the absorption capacity of Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/CN-150 increased significantly, while the binary and ternary composites containing Au had stronger absorption performance within the visible light range. This is ascribed to the Au particles with a representative characteristic absorption peak in the range of 500 - 650 nm, which has been observed in many literatures.
Claims.Claim: Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/CN-150 composite exhibits significantly increased absorption capacity compared to CN-150, and the addition of Au further enhances visible light absorption performance due to Au's characteristic absorption peak between 500 - 650 nm.
Claims.Topic: Enhanced absorption performance within visible light range

selectivity of 78%. Furthermore, the mild intercalation - exfoliation procedure yields high-quality graphene with negligible structural deterioration. (h) $^{7}$Li NMR spectra and (i) ICP-AES result for lithiated graphite.

reagent (biphenyl lithium), to realize the facile preparation of high-quality bilayer graphene under ambient temperature and pressure, as illustrated in Scheme 1 c. The Li-intercalation process occurs through the spontaneous reaction between graphite and the biphenyl lithium (Bp-Li) reagent at room temperature, benefiting from the strong reducing ability of BpLi.
